Situation1: The taxi driver ensures the cab remains neat and hygienic.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story:
I glanced at the dashboard clock as I wiped down the backseat, making sure every corner of my cab was spotless. As a taxi driver, I took pride in keeping my car immaculate for every passenger. Today, though, my mind was elsewhere. My family had called twice already, reminding me that the festival was about to begin. It was one of the most important Hindu ceremonies of the year, and I was expected to be there, to join in the prayers, the offerings, the rituals that connected me to my faith and my ancestors.

But the festival was far away, and I still had a few rides left before I could even think about leaving. If I rushed, I might make it in time, but the cab would be left unattended, and I wouldn’t have time to clean it after a long day’s work. My passengers expected a clean, professional ride, and I didn’t want to let them down. Yet, the thought of missing the festival gnawed at me. I could almost hear the temple bells and smell the incense, but I was stuck, torn between my duty to my passengers and my devotion to my faith.
